Section.Text: For greater certainty, a reference in any of sections 73 to 78 to the entering into, issuing, making or approving of any agreement, permit, licence, order or other similar document or authorization, includes renewing it, and a reference in any of those sections or in paragraph 97(1)(c) to any such document or authorization includes one that has been renewed.

Subsection.Text: Every person who is required by or under an Act of Parliament to ensure that an assessment of the environmental effects of a project is conducted, and every authority who makes a determination under paragraph 82(a) or (b) of the Impact Assessment Act in relation to a project, must, without delay, notify the competent minister or ministers in writing of the project if it is likely to affect a listed wildlife species or its critical habitat.

The person must identify the adverse effects of the project on the listed wildlife species and its critical habitat and, if the project is carried out, must ensure that measures are taken to avoid or lessen those effects and to monitor them. The measures must be taken in a way that is consistent with any applicable recovery strategy and action plans.
The following definitions apply in this section.

Definition.Text: person includes an association, an organization, a federal authority as defined in section 2 of the Impact Assessment Act, and any body that is set out in Schedule 4 to that Act. (personne)
project means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a designated project as defined in section 2 of the Impact Assessment Act or a project as defined in section 81 of that Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a project as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Yukon Environmental and Socio-economic Assessment Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a development as defined in subsection 111(1) of the Mackenzie Valley Resource Management Act. (projet)

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the competent minister, make an emergency order to provide for the protection of a listed wildlife species.
The competent minister must make the recommendation if he or she is of the opinion that the species faces imminent threats to its survival or recovery.
Before making a recommendation, the competent minister must consult every other competent minister.
The emergency order may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aquatic species,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: identify habitat that is necessary for the survival or recovery of the species in the area to which the emergency order relates, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: include provisions requiring the doing of things that protect the species and that habitat and provisions prohibiting activities that may adversely affect the species and that habitat;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a species that is a species of migratory birds protected by the Migratory Birds Convention Act, 1994,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: on federal land or in the exclusive economic zone of Canada,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: identify habitat that is necessary for the survival or recovery of the species in the area to which the emergency order relates, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: include provisions requiring the doing of things that protect the species and that habitat and provisions prohibiting activities that may adversely affect the species and that habitat, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: on land other than land referred to in subparagraph (i),

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: identify habitat that is necessary for the survival or recovery of the species in the area to which the emergency order relates, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: include provisions requiring the doing of things that protect the species and provisions prohibiting activities that may adversely affect the species and that habitat; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: with respect to any other species,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: on federal land, in the exclusive economic zone of Canada or on the continental shelf of Canada,

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: identify habitat that is necessary for the survival or recovery of the species in the area to which the emergency order relates, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: include provisions requiring the doing of things that protect the species and that habitat and provisions prohibiting activities that may adversely affect the species and that habitat, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: on land other than land referred to in subparagraph (i),

Clause.Label: (A)
Clause.Text: identify habitat that is necessary for the survival or recovery of the species in the area to which the emergency order relates, and

Clause.Label: (B)
Clause.Text: include provisions prohibiting activities that may adversely affect the species and that habitat.

Subsection.Text: An emergency order is exempt from the application of section 3 of the Statutory Instruments Act.

Section.Text: Despite subsection 80(2), the competent minister is not required to make a recommendation for an emergency order if he or she is of the opinion that equivalent measures have been taken under another Act of Parliament to protect the wildlife species.

If the competent minister is of the opinion that the species to which the emergency order relates would no longer face imminent threats to its survival or recovery even if the order were repealed, he or she must make a recommendation to the Governor in Council that the emergency order be repealed.

Subsection.Text: Subsections 32(1) and (2), section 33, subsections 36(1), 58(1), 60(1) and 61(1), regulations made under section 53, 59 or 71 and emergency orders do not apply to a person who is engaging in

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: activities related to public safety, health or national security, that are authorized by or under any other Act of Parliament or activities under the Health of Animals Act and the Plant Protection Act for the health of animals and plants; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: activities authorized under section 73, 74 or 78 by an agreement, permit, licence, order or similar document.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Authorization of activities under other Acts
Subsection.Text: A power under an Act described in paragraph (1)(a) may be used to authorize an activity prohibited by subsection 32(1) or (2), section 33, subsection 36(1), 58(1), 60(1) or 61(1), a regulation made under section 53, 59 or 71 or an emergency order only if the person exercising the power

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: determines that the activity is necessary for the protection of public safety, health, including animal and plant health, or national security; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: respects the purposes of this Act to the greatest extent possible.

Subsection.Text: Subsections 32(1) and (2), section 33, subsections 36(1), 58(1), 60(1) and 61(1) and regulations made under section 53, 59 or 71 do not apply to a person who is engaging in activities in accordance with conservation measures for wildlife species under a land claims agreement.

Subsections 32(1) and (2), section 33 and subsections 36(1), 58(1), 60(1) and 61(1) do not apply to a person who is engaging in activities that are permitted by a recovery strategy, an action plan or a management plan and who is also authorized under an Act of Parliament to engage in that activity, including a regulation made under section 53, 59 or 71.

Subsection 32(2) and paragraph 36(1)(b) do not apply to a person who possesses an individual of a listed extirpated, endangered or threatened species, or any part or derivative of such an individual, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it was in the person’s possession when the species was listed;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it is used by an aboriginal person for ceremonial or medicinal purposes, or it is part of ceremonial dress used for ceremonial or cultural purposes by an aboriginal person;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person acquired it legally in another country and imported it legally into Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the person acquired it by succession from someone who was entitled to possess it under this Act;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the person acquired it under circumstances that would afford them a defence under section 100 and the person possesses it only for as long as is necessary to donate it to a museum, a zoo, an educational institution, a scientific society or a government;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the person is, or is acting on behalf of, a museum, zoo, educational institution, scientific society or government and the person acquired it from someone who was entitled to possess it under this Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: it or the person is otherwise exempt by the regulations.

Section.Text: The Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the Minister after consultation with the Minister responsible for the Parks Canada Agency and the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, make regulations for the purpose of paragraph 83(5)(g).

Subsection.Text: A competent minister may designate any person or person of a class of persons to act as enforcement officers for the purposes of this Act.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Designation of provincial or territorial government employees
Subsection.Text: The competent minister may not designate any person or person of a class of persons employed by the government of a province or a territory unless that government agrees.

An enforcement officer must be provided with a certificate of designation as an enforcement officer in a form approved by the competent minister and, on entering any place under this Act, the officer must, if so requested, show the certificate to the occupant or person in charge of the place.

For the purposes of this Act, enforcement officers have all the powers of a peace officer, but the competent minister may specify limits on those powers when designating any person or person of a class of persons to act as enforcement officers.

For the purpose of investigations and other law enforcement activities under this Act, a competent minister may, on any terms and conditions that he or she considers necessary, exempt from the application of any provision of this Act, the regulations or an emergency order enforcement officers whom the competent minister has designated and who are carrying out duties or functions under this Act and persons acting under the direction and control of such enforcement officers.

For the purpose of ensuring compliance with any provision of this Act, the regulations or an emergency order, an enforcement officer may, subject to subsection (3), at any reasonable time enter and inspect any place in which the enforcement officer believes, on reasonable grounds, there is any thing to which the provision applies or any document relating to its administration, and the enforcement officer may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: open or cause to be opened any container that the enforcement officer believes, on reasonable grounds, contains that thing or document;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: inspect the thing and take samples free of charge;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: require any person to produce the document for inspection or copying, in whole or in part; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: seize any thing by means of or in relation to which the enforcement officer believes, on reasonable grounds, the provision has been contravened or that the enforcement officer believes, on reasonable grounds, will provide evidence of a contravention.

Subsection.Text: For the purposes of carrying out the inspection, the enforcement officer may stop a conveyance or direct that it be moved to a place where the inspection can be carried out.
The enforcement officer may not enter a dwelling-place except with the consent of the occupant or person in charge of the dwelling-place or under the authority of a warrant.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Authority to issue warrant for inspection of dwelling-place
Subsection.Text: On an ex parte application, a justice, as defined in section 2 of the Criminal Code, may issue a warrant, subject to any conditions specified in it, authorizing an enforcement officer to enter a dwelling-place, if the justice is satisfied by information on oath that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the conditions for entry described in subsection (1) exist in relation to the dwelling-place;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: entry to the dwelling-place is necessary for the purposes of the administration of this Act, the regulations or an emergency order; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: entry to the dwelling-place has been refused or there are reasonable grounds for believing that entry will be refused.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Authority to issue warrant for inspection of non-dwellings
Subsection.Text: On an ex parte application, a justice, as defined in section 2 of the Criminal Code, may issue a warrant, subject to any conditions specified in it, authorizing an enforcement officer to enter a place other than a dwelling-place, if the justice is satisfied by information on oath that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the conditions for entry described in subsection (1) exist in relation to that place;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: entry to that place is necessary for the purposes of the administration of this Act, the regulations or an emergency order;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: entry to that place has been refused, the enforcement officer is not able to enter without the use of force or the place was abandoned; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection (6), all reasonable attempts were made to notify the owner, operator or person in charge of the place.

Subsection.Text: The justice may waive the requirement to give notice referred to in subsection (5) if the justice is satisfied that attempts to give the notice would be unsuccessful because the owner, operator or person in charge is absent from the jurisdiction of the justice or that it is not in the public interest to give the notice.
In executing a warrant issued under subsection (4) or (5), an enforcement officer may not use force unless the use of force has been specifically authorized in the warrant.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Operation of computer system and copying equipment
Subsection.Text: In carrying out an inspection of a place under this section, an enforcement officer may

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: use or cause to be used any computer system at the place to examine any data contained in or available to the computer system;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: reproduce any record or cause it to be reproduced from the data in the form of a printout or other intelligible output;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: take a printout or other output for examination or copying; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: use or cause to be used any copying equipment at the place to make copies of the record.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Duty of person in possession or control
Subsection.Text: Every person who is in possession or control of a place being inspected under this section must permit the enforcement officer to do anything referred to in subsection (8).
Subject to subsections (2) to (4), if an enforcement officer seizes a thing under this Act or under a warrant issued under the Criminal Code,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: sections 489.1 and 490 of the Criminal Code apply; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the enforcement officer, or any person that the officer may designate, must retain custody of the thing subject to any order made under section 490 of the Criminal Code.

Subsection.Text: If the lawful ownership of or entitlement to the seized thing cannot be ascertained within 30 days after its seizure, the thing or any proceeds of its disposition are forfeited to Her Majesty in right of Canada, if the thing was seized by an enforcement officer employed in the public service of Canada or by the government of a territory, or to Her Majesty in right of a province, if the thing was seized by an enforcement officer employed by the government of that province.

If the seized thing is perishable, the enforcement officer may dispose of it or destroy it, and any proceeds of its disposition must be paid to the lawful owner or person lawfully entitled to possession of the thing, unless proceedings under this Act are commenced within 90 days after its seizure, in which case the proceeds must be retained by the enforcement officer pending the outcome of the proceedings.
An enforcement officer who seizes an individual of a species at risk may, at the time of the seizure, return the individual to the wild if the enforcement officer believes the individual to be alive.
The owner of the seized thing may abandon it to Her Majesty in right of Canada or a province.

Section.Text: Any thing that has been forfeited or abandoned under this Act is to be dealt with and disposed of as the competent minister may direct.

The lawful owner and any person lawfully entitled to possession of any thing seized, forfeited or abandoned under this Act and who has been convicted of an offence under this Act in relation to that thing, are jointly and severally, or solidarily, liable for all the costs of inspection, seizure, abandonment, forfeiture or disposition incurred by Her Majesty in excess of any proceeds of disposition of the thing that have been forfeited to Her Majesty under this Act.

An enforcement officer may, while carrying out powers, duties or functions under this Act, enter on and pass through or over private property without being liable for trespass or without the owner of the property having the right to object to that use of the property.
The owner or the person in charge of a place entered by an enforcement officer under section 86, and every person found in the place, must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: give the enforcement officer all reasonable assistance to enable the enforcement officer to carry out duties and functions under this Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide the enforcement officer with any information in relation to the administration of this Act, the regulations or an emergency order that the enforcement officer may reasonably require.

Section.Text: While an enforcement officer is exercising powers or carrying out duties or functions under this Act, no person shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: knowingly make any false or misleading statement, either orally or in writing, to the enforcement officer; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: otherwise obstruct or hinder the enforcement officer.

Subsection.Text: A person who is a resident of Canada and at least 18 years of age may apply to the competent minister for an investigation of whether an alleged offence has been committed or whether anything directed towards its commission has been done.
The application must be in a form approved by the competent minister and must include a solemn affirmation or declaration containing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the applicant;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a statement that the applicant is at least 18 years old and a resident of Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a statement of the nature of the alleged offence and the name of each person alleged to be involved;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a summary of the evidence supporting the allegations;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of each person who might be able to give evidence about the alleged offence, together with a summary of the evidence that the person might give, to the extent that information is available to the applicant;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any document or other material that the applicant believes should be considered in the investigation and, if possible, a copy of the document; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: details of any previous contact between the applicant and the competent minister about the alleged offence.

Subsection.Text: The competent minister must acknowledge receipt of the application within 20 days after receiving it and, subject to subsections (2) and (3), investigate all matters that he or she considers necessary to determine the facts relating to the alleged offence.
No investigation is required if the competent minister decides that the application is frivolous or vexatious.

If the competent minister decides not to conduct an investigation, he or she must, within 60 days after the application for investigation is received, give notice of the decision, with reasons, to the applicant.

Subsection.MarginalNote: When notice need not be given
Subsection.Text: The competent minister need not give the notice if an investigation in relation to the alleged offence is ongoing apart from the application.

Section.MarginalNote: Competent minister may send evidence to Attorney General
Section.Text: At any stage of the investigation, the competent minister may send any documents or other evidence to the Attorney General for a consideration of whether an offence has been or is about to be committed, and for any action that the Attorney General may wish to take.

Subsection.Text: The competent minister may suspend or conclude the investigation if he or she is of the opinion that the alleged offence does not require further investigation or the investigation does not substantiate the alleged offence or any other offence.

If the investigation is suspended, the competent minister must prepare a written report describing the information obtained during the investigation and stating the reasons for its suspension and the action, if any, that the competent minister has taken or proposes to take and send a copy of the report to the applicant. The competent minister must notify the applicant if the investigation is subsequently resumed.

When the investigation is concluded, the competent minister must prepare a written report describing the information obtained during the investigation and stating the reasons for its conclusion and the action, if any, that the competent minister has taken or proposes to take and send a copy of the report to the applicant and to each person whose conduct was investigated.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Personal information not to be disclosed
Subsection.Text: A copy of the report sent to a person whose conduct was investigated must not disclose the name or address of the applicant or any other personal information about him or her.

Subsection.MarginalNote: When report need not be sent
Subsection.Text: If another investigation in relation to the alleged offence is ongoing apart from the application, the competent minister need not send copies of a report described in subsection (2) or (3) until the other investigation is suspended or concluded.
Every person commits an offence who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: contravenes subsection 32(1) or (2), section 33, subsection 36(1), 58(1), 60(1) or 61(1) or section 91 or 92;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: contravenes a prescribed provision of a regulation or an emergency order;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: fails to comply with a term or condition of a permit issued under subsection 73(1); or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: fails to comply with an alternative measures agreement that the person has entered into under this Act.

Subsection.Text: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: on conviction on indictment,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a corporation, other than a non-profit corporation, to a fine of not more than $1,000,000,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a non-profit corporation, to a fine of not more than $250,000, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of any other person, to a fine of not more than $250,000 or to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years, or to both; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: on summary conviction,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a corporation, other than a non-profit corporation, to a fine of not more than $300,000,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of a non-profit corporation, to a fine of not more than $50,000, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of any other person, to a fine of not more than $50,000 or to imprisonment for a term of not more than one year, or to both.

Subsection.Text: Paragraph (1)(c) does not apply in respect of the failure to comply with any term or condition of any agreement, permit, licence, order or other similar document referred to in section 74 or subsection 78(1).
A regulation or emergency order may prescribe which of its provisions may give rise to an offence.
For a second or subsequent conviction, the amount of the fine may, despite subsection (1.1), be double the amount set out in that subsection.
A person who commits or continues an offence on more than one day is liable to be convicted for a separate offence for each day on which the offence is committed or continued.

A fine imposed for an offence involving more than one animal, plant or other organism may be calculated in respect of each one as though it had been the subject of a separate information and the fine then imposed is the total of that calculation.

If a person is convicted of an offence and the court is satisfied that monetary benefits accrued to the person as a result of the commission of the offence, the court may order the person to pay an additional fine in an amount equal to the court’s estimation of the amount of the monetary benefits, which additional fine may exceed the maximum amount of any fine that may otherwise be imposed under this Act.

For the purposes of subsection (1.1), non-profit corporation means a corporation, no part of the income of which is payable to, or is otherwise available for, the personal benefit of any proprietor, member or shareholder of the corporation.

Section.Text: If a corporation commits an offence, any officer, director or agent or mandatary of the corporation who directed, authorized, assented to, or acquiesced or participated in, the commission of the offence is a party to and guilty of the offence and is liable on conviction to the punishment provided for the offence, whether or not the corporation has been prosecuted or convicted.

Section.MarginalNote: Offences by employees or agents or mandataries
Section.Text: In any prosecution for an offence, the accused may be convicted of the offence if it is established that it was committed by an employee or an agent or mandatary of the accused, whether or not the employee, agent or mandatary has been prosecuted for the offence.
Due diligence is a defence in a prosecution for an offence.

A prosecution for an offence may be instituted, heard and determined in the place where the offence was committed, the subject-matter of the prosecution arose, the accused was apprehended or the accused happens to be or is carrying on business.
A court that imposes a sentence shall take into account, in addition to any other principles that it is required to consider, the following factors:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the harm or risk of harm caused by the commission of the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: whether the offender was found to have committed the offence intentionally, recklessly or inadvertently;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: whether the offender was found by the court to have been negligent or incompetent or to have shown a lack of concern with respect to the commission of the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any property, benefit or advantage received or receivable by the offender to which, but for the commission of the offence, the offender would not have been entitled;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any evidence from which the court may reasonably conclude that the offender has a history of non-compliance with legislation designed to protect wildlife species; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: all available sanctions that are reasonable in the circumstances, with particular attention to the circumstances of aboriginal offenders.

Subsection.Text: If a person is convicted of an offence, the convicting court may, in addition to any punishment imposed, order that any seized thing by means of or in relation to which the offence was committed, or any proceeds of its disposition, be forfeited to Her Majesty.
If the convicting court does not order the forfeiture, the seized thing, or the proceeds of its disposition, must be returned to its lawful owner or the person lawfully entitled to it.

Section.Text: If a fine is imposed on a person convicted of an offence, any seized thing, or any proceeds of its disposition, may be retained until the fine is paid or the thing may be sold in satisfaction of the fine and the proceeds applied, in whole or in part, in payment of the fine.

If a person is convicted of an offence, the court may, in addition to any punishment imposed and having regard to the nature of the offence and the circumstances surrounding its commission, make an order having any or all of the following effects:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prohibiting the person from doing any act or engaging in any activity that could, in the opinion of the court, result in the continuation or repetition of the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: directing the person to take any action that the court considers appropriate to remedy or avoid any harm to any wildlife species that resulted or may result from the commission of the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: directing the person to have an environmental audit conducted by a person of a class and at the times specified by the court and directing the person to remedy any deficiencies revealed during the audit;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: directing the person to publish, in any manner that the court considers appropriate, the facts relating to the commission of the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: directing the person to perform community service in accordance with any conditions that the court considers reasonable;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: directing the person to submit to the competent minister, on application to the court by the competent minister within three years after the conviction, any information about the activities of the person that the court considers appropriate;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: directing the person to pay a competent minister or the government of a province or a territory an amount for all or any of the cost of remedial or preventive action taken, or to be taken, by or on behalf of the competent minister or that government as a result of the commission of the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: directing the person to pay, in the manner prescribed by the court, an amount for the purpose of conducting research into the protection of the wildlife species in respect of which the offence was committed;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: directing the person to pay, in the manner prescribed by the court, an amount to an educational institution for scholarships for students enrolled in environmental studies;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: directing the person to post a bond or pay to the court an amount that the court considers appropriate for the purpose of ensuring compliance with any prohibition, direction or requirement under this section; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: requiring the person to comply with any other conditions that the court considers appropriate for securing the person’s good conduct and for preventing the person from repeating the offence or committing other offences.

Subsection.Text: If a person is convicted of an offence and the court suspends the passing of sentence under paragraph 731(1)(a) of the Criminal Code, the court may, in addition to any probation order made under that Act, make an order containing one or more of the prohibitions, directions or requirements mentioned in section 105.

If the person does not comply with the order or is convicted of another offence, within three years after the order is made, the court may, on the application of the prosecution, impose any sentence that could have been imposed if the passing of sentence had not been suspended.

Proceedings by way of summary conviction in respect of an offence may be commenced at any time within, but not later than, two years after the day on which the subject-matter of the proceedings became known to the competent minister.

A document appearing to have been issued by the competent minister, certifying the day on which the subject-matter of any proceedings became known to the competent minister, is admissible in evidence without proof of the signature or official character of the person appearing to have signed the document and is proof of the matter asserted in it.

A reference to the competent minister in this section includes a provincial or territorial minister if the competent minister has delegated responsibility for the enforcement of this Act, the regulations or an emergency order in the province or territory to the provincial or territorial minister and the offence is alleged to have been committed in the province or territory.

Section.MarginalNote: When alternative measures may be used

Subsection.Text: Alternative measures may be used to deal with a person who is alleged to have committed an offence, but only if it is not inconsistent with the purposes of this Act to do so and the following conditions are met:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the measures are part of a program of alternative measures authorized by the Attorney General, after consultation with the competent minister;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an information has been laid in respect of the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Attorney General, after consultation with the competent minister, is satisfied that the alternative measures would be appropriate, having regard to the nature of the offence, the circumstances surrounding its commission and the following factors, namely,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the protection of species at risk,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the person’s history of compliance with this Act,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: whether the offence is a repeated occurrence,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: any allegation that information is being or was concealed or other attempts to subvert the purposes and requirements of this Act are being or have been made, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: whether any remedial or preventive action has been taken by or on behalf of the person in relation to the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the person applies, in accordance with regulations made under paragraph 119(a), to participate in the alternative measures after having been informed of them;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the person and the Attorney General have concluded an agreement respecting the alternative measures within 180 days after the person has, with respect to the offence, been served with a summons, been issued an appearance notice or a release order or entered into an undertaking;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: before consenting to participate in the alternative measures, the person has been advised of the right to be represented by counsel;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the person accepts responsibility for the act or omission that forms the basis of the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: there is, in the opinion of the Attorney General, sufficient evidence to proceed with the prosecution of the offence; and

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the prosecution of the offence is not barred at law.

Subsection.Text: Alternative measures may not be used to deal with a person who

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: denies participation or involvement in the commission of the alleged offence; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: expresses the wish to have any charge against them dealt with by the court.

Subsection.Text: No admission, confession or statement accepting responsibility for a given act or omission made by a person as a condition of being dealt with by alternative measures is admissible in evidence against the person in any civil or criminal proceedings.
A court must dismiss a charge laid against a person in respect of an offence if alternative measures have been used to deal with the person in respect of the alleged offence and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the court is satisfied on a balance of probabilities that the person has totally complied with the agreement; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the court is satisfied on a balance of probabilities that the person has partially complied with the agreement and, in the opinion of the court, the prosecution of the charge would be unfair, having regard to the circumstances and the person’s performance with respect to the agreement.

Subsection.Text: The use of alternative measures in respect of a person who is alleged to have committed an offence is not a bar to any proceedings against the person under this Act.
This section does not prevent any person from laying an information, obtaining the issue or confirmation of any process, or proceeding with the prosecution of any offence, in accordance with law.
An alternative measures agreement may contain any terms and conditions, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: terms and conditions having any or all of the effects set out in section 105 or any other terms and conditions having any of the effects prescribed by regulations that the Attorney General, after consultation with the competent minister, considers appropriate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: terms and conditions relating to the costs associated with ensuring compliance with the agreement.

Subsection.Text: Any governmental organization may supervise compliance with the agreement.

Section.Text: An alternative measures agreement comes into effect on the day on which it is concluded or on any later day that is specified in the agreement and continues in effect for a period of not more than three years.

Section.MarginalNote: Filing in court for purpose of public access

Subsection.Text: The Attorney General must consult the competent minister before concluding an alternative measures agreement and, subject to subsection (5), must have the agreement filed with the court in which the information was laid within 30 days after the agreement is concluded. The agreement is to be filed as part of the court record of the proceedings to which the public has access.

A report relating to the administration of, and compliance with, the agreement must be filed with the same court by the Attorney General immediately after all the terms and conditions of the agreement have been complied with or the charges in respect of which the agreement was entered into have been dismissed.
Subject to subsection (4), if any of the following information is to be part of the agreement or the report, it must be set out in a schedule to the agreement or to the report:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: trade secrets of any person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: financial, commercial, scientific or technical information that is confidential information and is treated consistently in a confidential manner by any person;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: information the disclosure of which could reasonably be expected to result in material financial loss or gain to any person, or could reasonably be expected to prejudice the competitive position of any person; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: information the disclosure of which could reasonably be expected to interfere with contractual or other negotiations of any person.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Agreement on information to be in schedule
Subsection.Text: The parties to the agreement must agree on which information that is to be part of the agreement or the report is information that meets the requirements of paragraphs (3)(a) to (d).

Subsection.MarginalNote: How schedule is to be kept secret
Subsection.Text: The schedule is confidential and must not be filed with the court.
The competent minister must not disclose any information set out in a schedule to the agreement or to the report, except as authorized by section 117 or the Access to Information Act.

Despite section 579 of the Criminal Code, the Attorney General must, on filing an alternative measures agreement, stay the proceedings in respect of the alleged offence, or apply to the court for an adjournment of the proceedings, for a period of not more than one year after the expiry of the agreement.

Proceedings stayed under subsection (1) may be recommenced without laying a new information or preferring a new indictment, as the case may be, by the Attorney General giving notice of the recommencement to the clerk of the court in which the stay of the proceedings was entered. If no such notice is given within one year after the expiry of the agreement, the proceedings are deemed to have never been commenced.

Subject to subsections 111(2) and (3), the Attorney General may vary the terms and conditions of an alternative measures agreement on application by the person bound by the agreement and after consultation with the competent minister. The Attorney General must be of the opinion that the variation is desirable because of a material change in the circumstances since the agreement was concluded or last varied. The variation may include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: decreasing the period for which the agreement is to remain in force; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: relieving the person of compliance with any condition that is specified in the agreement, either absolutely or partially or for any period that the Attorney General considers desirable.

Subsection.Text: An agreement that has been varied must be filed in accordance with section 111 with the court in which the original agreement was filed.

Section.MarginalNote: Application of provisions dealing with records
Section.Text: Sections 115 to 117 apply only in respect of persons who have entered into an alternative measures agreement, regardless of the degree of their compliance with the terms and conditions of the agreement.

Section.MarginalNote: Disclosure of information by peace officer or enforcement officer
Section.Text: Where it is necessary in the conduct of an investigation of an offence, a peace officer or enforcement officer may disclose to a department or agency of a government in Canada any information in a record relating to an offence alleged to have been committed by a person, including the original or a copy of any fingerprints or photographs of the person.

Subsection.Text: The competent minister, any enforcement officer and any department or agency of a government in Canada with which the competent minister has entered into an agreement under section 10 may keep records and use information obtained as a result of the use of alternative measures to deal with a person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: for the purposes of an inspection under this Act or an investigation of an offence alleged to have been committed by a person;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in proceedings against a person under this Act;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: for the purpose of the administration of alternative measures programs; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: otherwise for the administration of this Act.

Subsection.Text: Any person or organization may keep records of information obtained by them as a result of supervising compliance with an alternative measures agreement and use the information for the purpose of supervising such compliance.
A record or information referred to in section 115 or 116 may be made available to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any judge or court for any purpose with respect to proceedings relating to offences under this or any other Act committed or alleged to have been committed by the person to whom the record relates;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any peace officer, enforcement officer or prosecutor

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for the purpose of investigating an offence under this or any other Act that the person is suspected on reasonable grounds of having committed, or in respect of which the person has been arrested or charged, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: for any purpose related to the administration of the case to which the record relates;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any member of a department or agency of a government in Canada, or any agent of such a government, that is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: engaged in the administration of alternative measures in respect of the person, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: preparing a report in respect of the person under this Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any other person who is deemed, or any person within a class of persons that is deemed, by a judge of a court to have a valid interest in the record, to the extent directed by the judge, if

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the judge is satisfied that the disclosure is desirable in the public interest for research or statistical purposes or in the interest of the proper administration of justice, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the person gives a written undertaking not to subsequently disclose the information except in accordance with subsection (2).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Subsequent disclosure for research or statistical purposes
Subsection.Text: If a record is made available for inspection to any person under paragraph (1)(d) for research or statistical purposes, that person may subsequently disclose information contained in the record, but may not disclose the information in any form that would reasonably be expected to identify the person to whom it relates.
A person to whom a record is authorized to be made available under this section may be given any information contained in the record and may be given a copy of any part of the record.
This section does not authorize the introduction into evidence of any part of a record that would not otherwise be admissible in evidence.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exception for public access to court record
Subsection.Text: For greater certainty, this section does not apply in respect of an alternative measures agreement, a varied alternative measures agreement or a report that is filed with the court in accordance with section 111.

Section.Text: The competent minister may enter into an agreement with a department or agency of a government in Canada respecting the exchange of information for the purpose of administering alternative measures or preparing a report in respect of a person’s compliance with an alternative measures agreement.
The competent minister may make regulations respecting the alternative measures that may be used for the purposes of this Act including regulations respecting

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the form and manner in which and the period within which an application to participate in the alternative measures is to be made, and the information that must be contained in or accompany the application;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the manner of preparing and filing reports relating to the administration of and compliance with alternative measures agreements;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the types of costs, and the manner of paying the costs, associated with ensuring compliance with alternative measures agreements; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the terms and conditions that may be included in an alternative measures agreement and the effects of those terms and conditions.

Section.Text: The Minister must establish a public registry for the purpose of facilitating access to documents relating to matters under this Act.

The Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the Minister after consultation with the Minister responsible for the Parks Canada Agency and the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, make regulations respecting the form of the public registry, the keeping of the public registry and access to it.

Despite any other Act of Parliament, no civil or criminal proceedings may be brought against Her Majesty in right of Canada, the Minister, the Minister responsible for the Parks Canada Agency, the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans or any person acting on behalf of or under the direction of any of them for the full or partial disclosure in good faith of any notice or other document through the public registry or any consequences of its disclosure.

Section.MarginalNote: Documents to be in public registry
Section.Text: The public registry shall contain every document required to be included in the public registry by this Act and the following documents, or a copy of the following documents:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: regulations and orders made under this Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: agreements entered into under section 10;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: COSEWIC’s criteria for the classification of wildlife species;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: status reports on wildlife species that COSEWIC has had prepared or has received with an application;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the List of Wildlife Species at Risk;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: codes of practice, national standards or guidelines established under this Act;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: agreements and reports filed under section 111 or subsection 113(2) or notices that those agreements or reports have been filed in court and are available to the public; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: every report made under sections 126 and 128.

Section.Text: The Minister, on the advice of COSEWIC, may restrict the release of any information required to be included in the public registry if that information relates to the location of a wildlife species or its habitat and restricting its release would be in the best interests of the species.

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the Minister and the President of the Treasury Board, after the Minister has consulted the Minister responsible for the Parks Canada Agency and the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prescribing the fees and charges, or the manner of determining them, that may be charged for agreements or permits under section 73, for amendments to or for the renewal of such agreements or permits, for copies of documents in the public registry and for the inclusion of a document in the public registry;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: exempting any person or class of persons from the requirement to pay any of those fees or charges; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: generally, in respect of any condition or any other matter in relation to the payment of those fees or charges.

Subsection.Text: A fee or charge required by the regulations to be paid constitutes a debt due to Her Majesty in right of Canada and may be recovered in any court of competent jurisdiction.

Section.Text: The Minister must annually prepare a report on the administration of this Act during the preceding calendar year and must have a copy of the report tabled in each House of Parliament within the first 15 days that it is sitting after the completion of the report. The report must include a summary addressing the following matters:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: COSEWIC’s assessments and the Minister’s response to each of them;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the preparation and implementation of recovery strategies, action plans and management plans;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all agreements made under sections 10 to 13;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: all agreements entered into or renewed under section 73, all permits issued or renewed under that section and all agreements and permits amended under section 75 or exempted under section 76;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: enforcement and compliance actions taken, including the response to any requests for investigation;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: regulations and emergency orders made under this Act; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: any other matters that the Minister considers relevant.

Subsection.Text: The Minister must, at least once every two years, convene a round table of persons interested in matters respecting the protection of wildlife species at risk in Canada to advise the Minister on those matters.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Recommendations to be in public registry
Subsection.Text: Any written recommendations from the round table must be included in the public registry.
The Minister must respond to any written recommendations from the round table within 180 days after receiving them and a copy of the Minister’s response must be included in the public registry.

Section.MarginalNote: Reports on status of wildlife species
Section.Text: Five years after this section comes into force and at the end of each subsequent period of five years, the Minister must prepare a general report on the status of wildlife species. The Minister must have the report tabled in each House of Parliament within the first 15 days that it is sitting after the completion of the report.

Five years after this section comes into force, a committee of the House of Commons, of the Senate or of both Houses of Parliament is to be designated or established for the purpose of reviewing this Act.

Heading.TitleText: Assessment of Wildlife Species Mentioned in the Schedules

Subsection.Text: COSEWIC must assess the status of each wildlife species set out in Schedule 2 or 3, and, as part of the assessment, identify existing and potential threats to the species and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: classify the species as extinct, extirpated, endangered, threatened or of special concern;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: indicate that COSEWIC does not have sufficient information to classify the species; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: indicate that the species is not currently at risk.

Subsection.Text: In the case of a species set out in Schedule 2, the assessment must be completed within 30 days after section 14 comes into force.

If an assessment of a wildlife species set out in Schedule 2 is not completed within the required time or, if there has been an extension, within the extended time, COSEWIC is deemed to have classified the species as indicated in Schedule 2.

In the case of a species set out in Schedule 3, the assessment must be completed within one year after the competent minister requests the assessment. If there is more than one competent minister with respect to the species, they must make the request jointly.

The Governor in Council may, on the recommendation of the Minister after consultation with the competent minister or ministers, by order, extend the time provided for the assessment of any species set out in Schedule 2 or 3. The Minister must include a statement in the public registry setting out the reasons for the extension.
Subsections 15(2) and (3) and 21(1) and section 25 apply with respect to assessments under subsection (1).
In making its assessment of a wildlife species, COSEWIC may take into account and rely on any report on the species that was prepared in the two-year period before this Act receives royal assent.

Section.Text: Section 27 applies in respect of a wildlife species referred to in section 130 that COSEWIC classifies as extinct, extirpated, endangered, threatened or of special concern or that is deemed to have been so classified.

If a wildlife species is added to the List by the Governor in Council as the result of an assessment under section 130, the recovery strategy for the species must be prepared within three years after the listing in the case of an endangered species, and within four years in the case of a threatened species.

If a wildlife species is added to the List by the Governor in Council as a species of special concern as the result of an assessment under section 130, the management plan for the species must be prepared within five years after the listing.

Section.Label: 134 to 141
Section.Text: [Amendments]
[Amendment]
Except for section 141.1, the provisions of this Act come into force on a day or days to be fixed by order of the Governor in Council.
